org.gearvrf

Class GVRBitmapTexture

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.GVRHybridObject
      • org.gearvrf.GVRImage
        • org.gearvrf.GVRBitmapTexture

  • public class GVRBitmapTexture
extends GVRImage
    Describes an uncompressed bitmap texture.

    A bitmap texture contains 2D uncompressed pixel data in RGB or RGBA format. This type of texture is inefficient because it wastes GPU memory. Mobile GPUs can directly render from compressed textures which use far less memory.

    See Also:
    GVRCompressedTexture

      • GVRBitmapTexture

        public GVRBitmapTexture(GVRContext gvrContext)

      • GVRBitmapTexture

        public GVRBitmapTexture(GVRContext gvrContext,
                        int width,
                        int height,
                        byte[] grayscaleData)
                 throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Create a new, grayscale texture, from an array of luminance bytes.
        Parameters:
        gvrContext - Current GVRContext
        width - Texture width, in pixels
        height - Texture height, in pixels
        grayscaleData - width * height bytes of gray scale data
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If width or height is <= 0, or if grayScaleData is null, or if grayscaleData.length < height * width

    • Method Detail

      • setBitmap

        public void setBitmap(Bitmap bmap)
        Copy a new Bitmap to the GPU texture. This one is also safe even in a non-GL thread. An updateGPU request on a non-GL thread will be forwarded to the GL thread and be executed before main rendering happens. Creating a new GVRImage is pretty cheap, but it's still not a totally trivial operation: it does involve some memory management and some GL hardware handshaking. Reusing the texture reduces this overhead (primarily by delaying garbage collection). Do be aware that updating a texture will affect any and all materials (and/or post effects that use the texture!
        Parameters:
        bmap - An Android Bitmap.
        Since:
        1.6.3

      • setBuffer

        public void setBuffer(int width,
                      int height,
                      int format,
                      int type,
                      java.nio.Buffer pixels)
        Copy a new texture from a Buffer to the GPU texture. This one is also safe even in a non-GL thread. An updateGPU request on a non-GL thread will be forwarded to the GL thread and be executed before main rendering happens. Creating a new GVRImage is pretty cheap, but it's still not a totally trivial operation: it does involve some memory management and some GL hardware handshaking. Reusing the texture reduces this overhead (primarily by delaying garbage collection). Do be aware that updating a texture will affect any and all materials (and/or post effects that use the texture!
        Parameters:
        width - Texture width, in texels
        height - Texture height, in texels
        format - Texture format
        type - Texture type
        pixels - A NIO Buffer with the texture

      • setBuffer

        public void setBuffer(int xoffset,
                      int yoffset,
                      int width,
                      int height,
                      int format,
                      int type,
                      java.nio.Buffer pixels)
        Copy a new texture subimage from a Buffer to the GPU texture. This one is also safe even in a non-GL thread. An updateGPU request on a non-GL thread will be forwarded to the GL thread and be executed before main rendering happens. Creating a new GVRImage is pretty cheap, but it's still not a totally trivial operation: it does involve some memory management and some GL hardware handshaking. Reusing the texture reduces this overhead (primarily by delaying garbage collection). Do be aware that updating a texture will affect any and all materials (and/or post effects that use the texture!
        Parameters:
        xoffset - Subimage texel offset in X direction
        yoffset - Subimage texel offset in Y direction
        width - Texture subimage width, in texels
        height - Texture subimage height, in texels
        format - Texture format
        type - Texture type
        pixels - A NIO Buffer with the texture

      • update

        public void update(int width,
                   int height,
                   byte[] grayscaleData)
        Copy new grayscale data to the GPU texture. This one is also safe even in a non-GL thread. An updateGPU request on a non-GL thread will be forwarded to the GL thread and be executed before main rendering happens. Be aware that updating a texture will affect any and all materials and/or post effects that use the texture!
        Parameters:
        width - width of grayscale image
        height - height of grayscale image
        grayscaleData - A byte array containing grayscale data
        Since:
        1.6.3
